Council against revote; declares Williams elected
Woody Herman signed For May
A formerly quiet June Week committee waved a contract in the air
yesterday and boasted of having signed Woody Herman's nationally famous dance band for May 31. William F Mehling, chairman, revealed at
the same time that Jimmy Dorsey was also "under wing" and that definite
announcements concerning his contract would be made next week.
Herman, who will play at the first of the June Week affairs, is now
playing at the Meado,wbrook Inn in New Jersey and broadcasts
daily. That his band rates with some
of the best swing aggregations in
the country is proved by the fact

Mitchell's resignation provokes action
Debaters elect 3
committee chairmen
Committee chairmen for the coming year were elected by the Debating council yesterday. With this action the practical work of the council
was ended for the year.
Charles Weiland and Carlo de Antonio were chosen entertainment
chairmen, succeeding Nathan Miller.
Edgar J Kassan was elected chairman of publicity.
Following the election, Arthur
Maass handed over the chair to Carrington Williams, the new president.
The council then voted to submit to
President Bowman a resolution recommending the reappointment of Dr
Mitchell.
Dr Pyles, the advisor and coach of
the council, was given a vote of
thanks by both the old and new
presidents. These men cited the intelligence and energy with which Dr
Pyles spurred the debaters on to better debating technique and an improved knowledge of the idiosynoracies of the English lang-uagie.
After the meeting it was announced
that Dr Pyles would be able to resume his association with the Debating council for the following year.

Downing suggestions to call a virtual tie, the Student Council announced the election of Carrington Williams to the office of president by
a vote of 238 to 226. In the same election, the new amendment to
the constitution calling for increased representation was passed. With
George
Thaler eliminated in the primaries, the Tuesday vote gave the
election to
Williams in preference to Butt by a scant two percent of the few
ballots
cast. This is the closest race seen at the Hopkins for years, as

John Hopkins plans to give Dr
Broadus Mitchell a rousing farewell.
Under the aegis of the "Help-Dr
Mitchell committee", a group of
forty key students, campus forces
are being organized to give him a
reception and also to petition President Bowman to tender him a reappointment.
The reception has been set for
May 14. Funds are being raised
through fraternities, campus organizations, and general solicitation. The
idea of a banquet was turned down
in favor of a reception, and the committee will rely on voluntary contributions, with the idea of bringing out
more students to bid Dr Mitchell
goodbye.
Progress has already been made
and the collection of contributions
are taking a prominent place in the
total.
While with one hand the committee is planning an impressive student demonstration as recognition
to Dr Mitchell on his departure, with
its other hand it is encouraging
requests that he be re-appointed.
These, many of which have already
been framed, are being sent to the
President, the Board of Trustees,
and Dr Mitchell. The latest such
resolution was issued yesterday by
Apha Tau Omega, a predominently
engineering fraternity.

Correspondence from Glenn Miller
indicates that he will cooperate with
the contest and play numbers appropriate to the situation. Miller left
Meadowbrok Inn in New Jersey last
week and was replaced by Woody
Herman who will be seen at June
Week on May 31. Miller gained rapid
popuarity by virtue of his daily radio
programs, and upon leaving the Inn
was reported to have been swamped
with contracts. His contract with
Hopkins will not be altered, however.
The band has been signed by the
Glen Island Casino in New York for
the summer months, and recently has
begun to make recordings. The records feature Marion Hutton and
Ray Eberle as vocalists and Miller
on the trombone. Miss Hutton is an
attractive blonde songstress who adds
the necessary feminine touch to the
comparatively young band. Eberle
is reported to be an unusually talented
young singer who will rival some of
the country's best.
The present goldfish gulping record
is held by "Les" Leibowitz of Forest
Park high school in Baltimore. "Les"
gulped 84 goldfish in 15 minutes.

One of the

youngest students

ever to

be elected president of the
Student council, personable Carrington Williams has only nineteen years
behind him.
Williams hails from Brookneal,Virginia, although he has been residing
with his aunt and uncle, Dr T Earl
Moore, one of the professors at City
College—Williams' Alma Mater. Living in Baltimore has not caused him
to lose his Su'thn accent, though.
And he's proud of his birthplace,
for it is within a few miles of Carter
Glass' home and the residence of
Patrick Henry, and they are connected with the art of oratory too.
Within one week at Hopkins, Carrington was elected president of student council, the Debating council,
and secretary-treasurer of the Tudor
and Stuart Club. He is also president of Delta Phi fraternity, and a
member of the Liberal club, the
German Refugee fund, and the
Honor Commission. Also interested
in dramatics, Williams is a major in
political science, and goes on record
as favoring the reappointment of
Dr Mitchell.

A survey of a cross-section of the
whole student body was completed
by the Honor commission last week
and submitted to the Student Council for action.
Of the 126 men interviewed, 101
felt that the "Honor system is functioning well as it stands." "This indicates to the Commission that no
radical changes are desirable in the
system as a whole," stated the report.
Since 25 students were not convinced
of this idea, "minor changes might
be effective and might be needed, the
Honor commission a :ees."
"A large proportion of the students
of the University would personally
warn a violator"; the question of a
personal warning was not put to the
freshmen but of the 70 upper classmen, 42 would do so. "This is one
of the most significant conclusions of
the report . . . The ultimate goal
that can be achieved under any Honor system is that of having 100 per
cent of the students willing to warn a
violator personally. That 60 per cent
of the Hopkins students questioned
are now willing to do so is encouraging."
Forty-six men of 116 would send an
Honor slip to a violator, while 30 of
these 116 were undecided. "Many of
those who would personally warn a
violator would not send an Honor
Slip . . . inspite of this fact, more
students would send slips than would
not. The Honor commission realizes
that the slip system leaves much to
be desired. However since the system

Alumni plan homecoming
Heany announces
plans for festivities
on May 20
Arrangements are rapidly reaching completion for the annual homecoming day May 20, according to
Norman Heany, of the Alumni association.
At a meeting held last Thursday,
O D K, inuagurators of last years
alumni day, decided to turn over the
sponsorship of the forthcoming event
to the Alumni association because
they felt that it was definitely a part
of the association's work.
The program scheduled for the entertainment of former undergraduates includes a general assembly in
Levering hall, where members of the
faculty will be present, and President Bowman will speak. At 12:30
there will be a luncheon for all
alumni, forrowed at 2:30 by the Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game and the
Mason-Dixon conference track meet.
In the late afternoon and evening,
the fraternities on the campus will
hold an open house for old fraters
and their friends.
Cards have been sent out to the
various fraternal organizations, and
(Continued on Page 4).

elected by landslides.
Cause for a new election was seen
in the fact that the students absent
on the geology trip could easily influence the vote. However, at a
special student council meeting on
Wednesday it was unanimously decided that the election should be
final.
Williams, favoring campus democracy, won the election with the following platform:
1. Non-compulsory assemblies.
2. Control of non-athletic undergraduate activities by the
student body, and not by the
college administration or an uncontrolled student council.
3. Reorganization proposal allowing for greater sophomore
representation and elimination
of ex-officio members.
4. Continuance of referendum,
recall, and discussion meetings.
5. Conscientious selection of
student councilmen by use of
platforms if student government
is to become more representative.
Adding greatly to student voice in
the government, the passage of the
amendment eliminates ex-officio
members of the council and adds one
senior and one sophomore to be
elected by the respective classes. The
members unseated are the head of
the Athletic board and the president
of the senior class.
The amendment also provides for
the election of an officer pro-tern in
case of the absence of the president.
Elections for the Senior class representatives will be held in the near
future. Officers to assist Williams
and committees will be elected next
year. Platforms of the Senior class
representative aspirants have been
posted on the bulletin board in
Levering.

Columnists -despise war:

Nation's penmen split
On America's part
in War vs Peace drama
Walter Winchell: "America. must
learn that her sons abroad will bring
monuments to her glory, but her sons
at home are a monument to her common sense. The future of America
youth is on top of American soil—
not underneath European dirt."
Boake Carter: "The question ..,is:
Do we or do we not want to help one
gang of tnieves against another gang
of thieves? . . . We saved the first
crop of thieves twenty years ago—
and made the world safe for a new
set."
Westbrook Pegler: "The President
is making the decisions which commit the country to the job of bottle
holder in the democratic corner,
should war come . . . For God's sake
don't anybody blow a bugle now."

HOMEWOOD,
Buskin and Sock ...

Theatre and entertainment folk
busy on Eastern shore
Katherine Cornell salutes Baltimore as "lucky"
FROM HERE AND THERE

Kay (Hi Ya everybody) Kyser and his gang have camped for a while
at New York's Hotel Pennsylvania. To his evergrowing repertoire he has
added an unmistakable and authentic southern drawl that "slays" the
customers ... Ole Earl Carroll will shortly open another nite club, and this
time it's gonna be Manhattan . . . Burgess Meredith and Frank Craven
are slated to open in the revival "The First Year" this summer at the
World's Fair . . . Bob Taylor of Cal is taking his recent he-man roles
seriously. Latest report has it he's opening a ranch in San Ferando valley
to raise pigeons—of all things ... Stokowski and Garbo still arm in arm at
Santa Barbara, with the odds slightly favoring the former .. . Stage version
Hugh S. Johnson: "No matter who
wins, the next world war will permanently destroy the democracy of
every nation that gets into it."
Dorothy Thompson: "All that has
flowed from Christianity is being done
to death . . . The Nazi-Fascist movement cannot be isolated except by
resistance."—Life Magazine..

ON THE RECORD RACK:

Nursery rhymes set to swing
by Basie, Kemp; Coolidge string
quartet records Loeffler
Count Basic swarms all over his
piano in BOOGIE, WOOGIE and
HOW LONG, HOW LONG, BLUES
(Decca), and gets a bit more assistance from, his group in ROCK-ABYE BASIE and BABY DON'T TELL
ON ME (Voca/iion). He weaves a
cool, frolicsome rhythm. Simple? Art
and stuff. But the effect is a dozen
beers the night after exams. Maestro
Hal Kemp finds THREE LITTLE
FISHES just his meat, and this little
novelty balled is good to hear. It goes
with UNDER THE CHESTNUT
TREE, another, nursery rhyme
Tommy Dorsey relates GOT NO
TIME in creditable instrumental
style, and throws LITTLE SKIPPER
a bit slower. Pass, friend. A desirable double feature is RED SKIES IN
THE NIGHT, with SNUG AS A BUG
in tow. Sammy Kaye is responsible.
Vocals by Tommy Ryan and Charlie
Wilson. (victor)
An uninspired sax run (too much
control), is volunteered by Duke Ellington in PUSSY WILLOW.
SUBTLE LAMENT is modish, however, with the piano dallying in the
daisies. But HOME JAMES and
JESSE by Harry James—Hal-le-yea
man! New Orleans and the dirty tradition! Tear trumpet pitches, backed
by a swell instrumental outfield to
catch the hot solos. (Brunswick)

The musical essay is much subtler
than Beecham's direction would have

SPORTS PAGE

SPORTSCOPE
Edged out by the cadets of Army,
the Jays had their clean record marred. The game was hard fought and
close throughout. Getting off to a
2-1 lead at the quarter, the Black and
Blue stretched it to 5-3 at the half.
Opening the final half, the Cadets
immediately rallied to gain the lead.
The 6-3 count of this period in Army's
favor, made the total Army 9, Hopkins 8.
Both teams tallied three each in
the final quarter for the 12-11 win of
Army. Outstanding was Penniman,
who lead the Jays with six tallies.

Maryland Heads
Toward Title
While the Morrillmen played well
in defeat, national lacrosse honors
faded. With Maryland undefeated, the
Terps seem to be the outstanding
contenders for the national crown.
The only strong opposition left for
Maryland is Princeton, Navy, and
Hopkins.
With Navy beating Princeton,
Mount Washington topping Navy, and
Maryland defeating Mount Washington Hopkins has the chance to upset
Maryland. Such an occurence would
place the Jays high in national rankings.
Scheduled for a home game tomorrow is Loyola and Hopkins.
Loyola has compiled three wins
against one defeat. The lone setback came at the hands of St John's
14-4.
This contest should find the Jays
emerging victorious. In all events,
it is the last breather for the Morrillmen.
Following in order will be Princeton, St John's and Maryland. At this
point Hopkins should top St John's,
be a slight favorite over Princeton,
and the underdog in the Maryland
clash.

Diamond Record,
2 Wins, 2 Losses
Returning to Coach Owings and
his nine, one finds that the squad has
netted two victories and two defeats
to date. After winning the opener
from Wilson teachers, the Jays were

set back by Drew university by a 3-2
count.
Haverford was the third opponent;
Hopkins won 11-6. Against American
university, last Saturday, the Jays
muffed a chance to make it two in
a row. After getting off to a 2-0
lead in the first, the nine relinquished
the pace and trailed until the fifth
where they tied at 7-7.
American university won the game
by scoring the deciding runs in the
seventh inning. Aided by an error,
the visitors scored twice to make the
count 9-7. The contest ended with a
a total of 11 errors credited; six for
the Black and Blue and five for the
visitors.
A reminder to the nine and spectators alike is that with the record of
won and loss at 2-2, the Jays will
have to snap the caliber of play of the
American game if they hope to ring
up a 5-3 record of last year.

Tennis and
Golf Progress
Perhaps unnoticed is the play of
the tennis squad. To date the netmen
have yet to be defeated. Among the
victories is the 7-3 win over Swarthmore.
Last year the Pennsylvania lads
were one of the three teams that
topped the Jays. This year's win
marks the present squad stronger
than the '38 edition.
On the other hand the golfers have
not compiled such an impressive record. In three matches to date, the
Jays have dropped two and tied one.
With three contests remaining the
team hopes to improve its record.

Trackmen Upset
By Catholic U
Opening the '39 season last Saturday against Catholic university the
track team dropped the meet by a
71-55 score.
The dopesters had picked Hopkins
to win, and the outcome was somewhat of a surprise.
Today (Friday) the Jays journey
to Haverford to clash in another
meet. Haverford should offer stiff
competition, and, if last year's score
is a comparison, is the favorite. The
Pennsylvania speedsters topped Hopkins 89-37 in '38.

Tomorrow afternoon the Blue Jay
nine will tussle with the strong
Swarthmore
aggregation
at the
Hopkins home field. The Owingsmen
will be out there gunning for a victory in order to put them back in
the win column.
So far the Jays have played .500
ball winning two and dropping two.
One game, against Loyola, was
rained out on Wednesday, but it will
be played at a later date. After a
sloppy setback 9-7 at the hands of
Moe Brown of American University,
conqueror of Georgetown U. and
Yale, the Hopkins nine will be trying
hard to win this next ball game.
Coach Bobby Owings has drilled
his keystone men in the art of manufacturing double plays and has
tutored the entire team in base
running and sliding properly. Much
of the daily practice is devoted to
batting. Outstanding in the stickwielding sessions, are Bateman, Callahan, Olson, and Schwartzman, all
of whom are hitting the ball sharply.
Eager, Jay substitute catcher, is
rapidly learning the tricks of the
trade and is showing good form at
the plate. Baetjer Miller, "Irv" Milberg, and "Brownie" Dischinger, the
three Jay moundsmen, have been
working hard in practices. The following men will lineup tomorrow for
the underdog Jay nine against the
favorite Swarthmore ball club. Didusch, shortstop, Salvia, second base,
Bateman, centerfield, Callahan, first
base, Olson, right field, Hofmann,
left field, Schwartzman, catcher.
Capt. Alperstein, third base, and
either Milberg or Miller on the
mound.

Jay Cindermen
toppled 71-55
by Catholic U
Last Saturday afternoon a strong
Catholic U track team handed the
"Mercurys" of Johns Hopkins a decisive 71 to 55 defeat.
The highlights of the meet were
established when Corbett of C U set
two new meet and stadium records
in the one mile and two mile races.
Corbett, however, was not the only
record breaker, because two Jay
tracksters established new records.
Rosenthal and O'Neil in the shot put
and 220 yard low hurdles respectively.
Three men stood out for the "Galloping Crusaders" namely; Wall, Corbett, and Cooper. Glazer, Rosenthal,
Lankford, O'Neil, and Pardew of J
H U did "right well" for themselves
and the university. Hopkins however, suffered a severe blow when
Lankford was injured. This will hurt
Jay hopes in future meets very much.

Jack Donohue, sensational freshman pitcher
on the Hopkins varsity baseball team, has signed
a contract with the Salisbury club of the Eastern
Shore League, to play for them this summer. It
was disclosed that Donohue will receive a salary
of eighty dollars a month, which covers his room
and board. This announcement was a severe blow
to Coach Bill Owings who was banking strongly
on Jack to serve as the bulwark of the staff.

By L Wethered Barron, jr
There is fear among older members of Scabbard and Blade that they
have taken under their wing nine incipient fascists. Major Bill Schmied
and Phi Beta Street Baldwin were beaten across their heads, shoulders
and legs by sections of rubber hose in the hands of initiates they were
inducting Saturday night.
Another man bit a dog when Sergt Jerry Carleton, while marching
guard past Levering hall about 10:30, slugged an attacker, Lt Willie Hooper,
with his rifle-butt. Hooper was unconscious for two minute. There
were no apologies.
These virile juniors, who have demonstrated their fitness for admission
to Scabbard and Blade by wearing
uniforms for six weeks and accepting orders from such people as
military fraternity brothers, were
subjected to a grueling night of
the
blindfold
through
marching
briars and thickets of Howard
county being forced to pitch tents
thus on unsuitable "terrain" and to
keep awake until after 7 o'clock Sunday morning.
The site. of the Peace strike was
chosen by the initiators as a place
to pitch five tents and to give instruction in the saber manual, Tactical problems, including attacking
lovers, uh, machine gun nests in the
bushes and woods of Wyman park,
also engaged their attention.
To get back to the first paragraph,
the origin of the rubber hose, which
the wild neophytes were toting,
mystified their victims. In the past
those about to become men have
armed themselves for the occasion
with nothing more menacing than a
pint. In many quarters uses of them
to perform operations other than
squirting water have been branded
as "unAmerican."
Between 6:45 and 7:30 Sunday
morning the ritual of the formal
initiation was administratered to
Enders,
Spencer, Johnny
Doug
Frank Kohlhof, Bill Janney, Tom
Schreiber, Felix Ireland, Gene Mihalyka, Al Smith, and Carleton
Schmied, as Captain of Scabbard and
Blade company, president.
Breakfast was served, after which
everybody went about his business.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE

Don Kirkwood says •
With a Glenn Miller dance in the offing next week and June Week
plans taking shape, Don Kirkwood, chairman of the B S A, is already
thinking of next year and announced a tentative policy yesterday.
Kirkwood, who is a Junior, and will return as chairman of the Board
in '39, plans to correct mistakes made this year by signing bands early
and making dances more "Hopkins-like."
He did not commit himself to any closed "name-band" dance, however.
Among the plans announced was one for a \ small dance every three

weeks which will be open only to
students. This policy will be abandoned when a big dance or a class affair is in the offing. The price of admission will be nominal and a local
orchestra will be used.

1Kirkwood also declared that he
would begin at the outset of the next
school year to sign two big bands to
play at affairs on Washington's birthday and Thanksgiving respectively.
The sound financial state of the B S
A at present due to the success of
the Artie !Shaw dance will allow the
board to make arrangements early
without the necessity of having
pledges signed.
The B S A with Kirkwood as chairman was installed at the beginning
of this year to replace the "purged"
Cotillion board. A dispute which promulgated a campus fight for more
"student democracy" emanated from
the purge. At that time William
Lamble, chairman of the Cotillion
board, stated that his group was the
only one which could get name bands
and consequently he hoped that students would favor it.

After the meeting it was announced
that Dr Pyles would be able to resume his association with the Debating council for the following year.

John Hopkins plans to give Dr
Broadus Mitchell a rousing farewell.
Under the aegis of the "Help-Dr
Mitchell committee", a group of
forty key students, campus forces
are being organized to give him a
reception and also to petition President Bowman to tender him a reappointment.
The reception has been set for
May 14. Funds are being raised
through fraternities, campus organizations, and general solicitation. The
idea of a banquet was turned down
in favor of a reception, and the committee will rely on voluntary contributions, with the idea of bringing out
more students to bid Dr Mitchell
goodbye.
Progress has already been made
and the collection of contributions
are taking a prominent place in the
total.
While with one hand the committee is planning an impressive student demonstration as recognition
to Dr Mitchell on his departure, with
its other hand it is encouraging
requests that he be re-appointed.
These, many of which have already
been framed, are being sent to the
President, the Board of Trustees,
and Dr Mitchell. The latest such
resolution was issued yesterday by
Apha Tau Omega, a predominently
engineering fraternity.

The band has been signed by the
Glen Island Casino in New York for

on the trombone. Miss Hutton is an

the necessary feminine touch to the
comparatively young band. Eberle
is reported to be an unusually talented
young singer who will rival some of
the country's best.
The present goldfish gulping record
is held by "Les" Leibowitz of Forest
Park high school in Baltimore. "Les"
gulped 84 goldfish in 15 minutes.

One of the

youngest students

ever to

be elected president of the
Student council, personable Carrington Williams has only nineteen years
behind him.
Williams hails from Brookneal,Virginia, although he has been residing
with his aunt and uncle, Dr T Earl
Moore, one of the professors at City
College—Williams' Alma Mater. Living in Baltimore has not caused him
to lose his Su'thn accent, though.
And he's proud of his birthplace,
for it is within a few miles of Carter
Glass' home and the residence of
Patrick Henry, and they are connected with the art of oratory too.
Within one week at Hopkins, Carrington was elected president of student council, the Debating council,
and secretary-treasurer of the Tudor
and Stuart Club. He is also president of Delta Phi fraternity, and a
member of the Liberal club, the
German Refugee fund, and the
Honor Commission. Also interested
in dramatics, Williams is a major in
political science, and goes on record
as favoring the reappointment of
Dr Mitchell.

A survey of a cross-section of the
whole student body was completed
by the Honor commission last week
and submitted to the Student Council for action.
Of the 126 men interviewed, 101
felt that the "Honor system is functioning well as it stands." "This indicates to the Commission that no
radical changes are desirable in the
system as a whole," stated the report.
Since 25 students were not convinced
of this idea, "minor changes might
be effective and might be needed, the
Honor commission a :ees."
"A large proportion of the students
of the University would personally
warn a violator"; the question of a
personal warning was not put to the
freshmen but of the 70 upper classmen, 42 would do so. "This is one
of the most significant conclusions of
the report . . . The ultimate goal
that can be achieved under any Honor system is that of having 100 per
cent of the students willing to warn a
violator personally. That 60 per cent
of the Hopkins students questioned
are now willing to do so is encouraging."
Forty-six men of 116 would send an
Honor slip to a violator, while 30 of
these 116 were undecided. "Many of
those who would personally warn a
violator would not send an Honor
Slip . . . inspite of this fact, more
students would send slips than would
not. The Honor commission realizes
that the slip system leaves much to
be desired. However since the system

Heany announces
plans for festivities
on May 20
Arrangements are rapidly reaching completion for the annual homecoming day May 20, according to
Norman Heany, of the Alumni association.
At a meeting held last Thursday,
O D K, inuagurators of last years
alumni day, decided to turn over the
sponsorship of the forthcoming event
to the Alumni association because
they felt that it was definitely a part
of the association's work.
The program scheduled for the entertainment of former undergraduates includes a general assembly in
Levering hall, where members of the
faculty will be present, and President Bowman will speak. At 12:30
there will be a luncheon for all
alumni, forrowed at 2:30 by the Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game and the
Mason-Dixon conference track meet.
In the late afternoon and evening,
the fraternities on the campus will
hold an open house for old fraters
and their friends.
Cards have been sent out to the
various fraternal organizations, and
(Continued on Page 4).

elected by landslides.
Cause for a new election was seen
in the fact that the students absent
on the geology trip could easily influence the vote. However, at a
special student council meeting on
Wednesday it was unanimously decided that the election should be
final.
Williams, favoring campus democracy, won the election with the following platform:
1. Non-compulsory assemblies.
2. Control of non-athletic undergraduate activities by the
student body, and not by the
college administration or an uncontrolled student council.
3. Reorganization proposal allowing for greater sophomore
representation and elimination
of ex-officio members.
4. Continuance of referendum,
recall, and discussion meetings.
5. Conscientious selection of
student councilmen by use of
platforms if student government
is to become more representative.
Adding greatly to student voice in
the government, the passage of the
amendment eliminates ex-officio
members of the council and adds one
senior and one sophomore to be
elected by the respective classes. The
members unseated are the head of
the Athletic board and the president
of the senior class.
The amendment also provides for
the election of an officer pro-tern in
case of the absence of the president.
Elections for the Senior class representatives will be held in the near
future. Officers to assist Williams
and committees will be elected next
year. Platforms of the Senior class
representative aspirants have been
posted on the bulletin board in
Levering.

Kay (Hi Ya everybody) Kyser and his gang have camped for a while
at New York's Hotel Pennsylvania. To his evergrowing repertoire he has

customers ... Ole Earl Carroll will shortly open another nite club, and this
time it's gonna be Manhattan . . . Burgess Meredith and Frank Craven
are slated to open in the revival "The First Year" this summer at the
World's Fair . . . Bob Taylor of Cal is taking his recent he-man roles
seriously. Latest report has it he's opening a ranch in San Ferando valley
to raise pigeons—of all things ... Stokowski and Garbo still arm in arm at
Santa Barbara, with the odds slightly favoring the former .. . Stage version

every nation that gets into it."

flowed from Christianity is being done
to death . . . The Nazi-Fascist movement cannot be isolated except by

SPORTS PAGE

SPORTSCOPE
Edged out by the cadets of Army,
the Jays had their clean record marred. The game was hard fought and
close throughout. Getting off to a
2-1 lead at the quarter, the Black and
Blue stretched it to 5-3 at the half.
Opening the final half, the Cadets
immediately rallied to gain the lead.
The 6-3 count of this period in Army's
favor, made the total Army 9, Hopkins 8.
Both teams tallied three each in
the final quarter for the 12-11 win of
Army. Outstanding was Penniman,
who lead the Jays with six tallies.

Maryland Heads
Toward Title
While the Morrillmen played well
in defeat, national lacrosse honors
faded. With Maryland undefeated, the
Terps seem to be the outstanding
contenders for the national crown.
The only strong opposition left for
Maryland is Princeton, Navy, and
Hopkins.
With Navy beating Princeton,
Mount Washington topping Navy, and
Maryland defeating Mount Washington Hopkins has the chance to upset
Maryland. Such an occurence would
place the Jays high in national rankings.
Scheduled for a home game tomorrow is Loyola and Hopkins.
Loyola has compiled three wins
against one defeat. The lone setback came at the hands of St John's
14-4.
This contest should find the Jays
emerging victorious. In all events,
it is the last breather for the Morrillmen.
Following in order will be Princeton, St John's and Maryland. At this
point Hopkins should top St John's,
be a slight favorite over Princeton,
and the underdog in the Maryland
clash.

Diamond Record,
2 Wins, 2 Losses
Returning to Coach Owings and
his nine, one finds that the squad has
netted two victories and two defeats
to date. After winning the opener
from Wilson teachers, the Jays were

set back by Drew university by a 3-2
count.
Haverford was the third opponent;
Hopkins won 11-6. Against American
university, last Saturday, the Jays
muffed a chance to make it two in
a row. After getting off to a 2-0
lead in the first, the nine relinquished
the pace and trailed until the fifth
where they tied at 7-7.
American university won the game
by scoring the deciding runs in the
seventh inning. Aided by an error,
the visitors scored twice to make the
count 9-7. The contest ended with a
a total of 11 errors credited; six for
the Black and Blue and five for the
visitors.
A reminder to the nine and spectators alike is that with the record of
won and loss at 2-2, the Jays will
have to snap the caliber of play of the
American game if they hope to ring
up a 5-3 record of last year.

Tennis and
Golf Progress
Perhaps unnoticed is the play of
the tennis squad. To date the netmen
have yet to be defeated. Among the
victories is the 7-3 win over Swarthmore.
Last year the Pennsylvania lads
were one of the three teams that
topped the Jays. This year's win
marks the present squad stronger
than the '38 edition.
On the other hand the golfers have
not compiled such an impressive record. In three matches to date, the
Jays have dropped two and tied one.
With three contests remaining the
team hopes to improve its record.

Trackmen Upset
By Catholic U
Opening the '39 season last Saturday against Catholic university the
track team dropped the meet by a
71-55 score.
The dopesters had picked Hopkins
to win, and the outcome was somewhat of a surprise.
Today (Friday) the Jays journey
to Haverford to clash in another
meet. Haverford should offer stiff
competition, and, if last year's score
is a comparison, is the favorite. The
Pennsylvania speedsters topped Hopkins 89-37 in '38.

Jay stickmen conquered by Cadets

Tomorrow afternoon the Blue Jay
nine will tussle with the strong
Swarthmore
aggregation
at the
Hopkins home field. The Owingsmen
will be out there gunning for a victory in order to put them back in
the win column.
So far the Jays have played .500
ball winning two and dropping two.
One game, against Loyola, was
rained out on Wednesday, but it will
be played at a later date. After a
sloppy setback 9-7 at the hands of
Moe Brown of American University,
conqueror of Georgetown U. and
Yale, the Hopkins nine will be trying
hard to win this next ball game.
Coach Bobby Owings has drilled
his keystone men in the art of manufacturing double plays and has
tutored the entire team in base
running and sliding properly. Much
of the daily practice is devoted to
batting. Outstanding in the stickwielding sessions, are Bateman, Callahan, Olson, and Schwartzman, all
of whom are hitting the ball sharply.
Eager, Jay substitute catcher, is
rapidly learning the tricks of the
trade and is showing good form at
the plate. Baetjer Miller, "Irv" Milberg, and "Brownie" Dischinger, the
three Jay moundsmen, have been
working hard in practices. The following men will lineup tomorrow for
the underdog Jay nine against the
favorite Swarthmore ball club. Didusch, shortstop, Salvia, second base,
Bateman, centerfield, Callahan, first
base, Olson, right field, Hofmann,
left field, Schwartzman, catcher.
Capt. Alperstein, third base, and
either Milberg or Miller on the
mound.

record breaker, because two Jay
tracksters established new records.
Rosenthal and O'Neil in the shot put

and the university. Hopkins however, suffered a severe blow when
Lankford was injured. This will hurt
Jay hopes in future meets very much.

Jack Donohue, sensational freshman pitcher
on the Hopkins varsity baseball team, has signed
a contract with the Salisbury club of the Eastern
Shore League, to play for them this summer. It
was disclosed that Donohue will receive a salary
of eighty dollars a month, which covers his room
and board. This announcement was a severe blow
to Coach Bill Owings who was banking strongly
on Jack to serve as the bulwark of the staff.

Scabbard and Blade
initiation Saturday night

Freshman group

Dr H Bentley Glass of Goucher
college spoke on the subject "Alco-

By L Wethered Barron, jr
There is fear among older members of Scabbard and Blade that they
have taken under their wing nine incipient fascists. Major Bill Schmied
and Phi Beta Street Baldwin were beaten across their heads, shoulders
and legs by sections of rubber hose in the hands of initiates they were
inducting Saturday night.
Another man bit a dog when Sergt Jerry Carleton, while marching
guard past Levering hall about 10:30, slugged an attacker, Lt Willie Hooper,
with his rifle-butt. Hooper was unconscious for two minute. There
were no apologies.
These virile juniors, who have demonstrated their fitness for admission
to Scabbard and Blade by wearing
uniforms for six weeks and accepting orders from such people as
military fraternity brothers, were
subjected to a grueling night of
the
blindfold
through
marching
briars and thickets of Howard
county being forced to pitch tents
thus on unsuitable "terrain" and to
keep awake until after 7 o'clock Sunday morning.
The site. of the Peace strike was
chosen by the initiators as a place
to pitch five tents and to give instruction in the saber manual, Tactical problems, including attacking
lovers, uh, machine gun nests in the
bushes and woods of Wyman park,
also engaged their attention.
To get back to the first paragraph,
the origin of the rubber hose, which
the wild neophytes were toting,
mystified their victims. In the past
those about to become men have
armed themselves for the occasion
with nothing more menacing than a

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE

Don Kirkwood says •
With a Glenn Miller dance in the offing next week and June Week
plans taking shape, Don Kirkwood, chairman of the B S A, is already
thinking of next year and announced a tentative policy yesterday.
Kirkwood, who is a Junior, and will return as chairman of the Board
in '39, plans to correct mistakes made this year by signing bands early
and making dances more "Hopkins-like."
He did not commit himself to any closed "name-band" dance, however.
Among the plans announced was one for a \ small dance every three

weeks which will be open only to
students. This policy will be abandoned when a big dance or a class affair is in the offing. The price of admission will be nominal and a local
orchestra will be used.

1Kirkwood also declared that he
would begin at the outset of the next
school year to sign two big bands to
play at affairs on Washington's birthday and Thanksgiving respectively.
The sound financial state of the B S
A at present due to the success of
the Artie !Shaw dance will allow the
board to make arrangements early
without the necessity of having
pledges signed.
The B S A with Kirkwood as chairman was installed at the beginning
of this year to replace the "purged"
Cotillion board. A dispute which promulgated a campus fight for more
"student democracy" emanated from
the purge. At that time William
Lamble, chairman of the Cotillion
board, stated that his group was the
only one which could get name bands
and consequently he hoped that students would favor it.

The highlight of the day will be
the reunion dinners of classes of
five years intervals between 1894
and 1934, which will be held on and
near the campus in the evening. The
class of 1899, however, will not hold
a reunion dinner due to the fact

exercises held at the Hopkins last
month. The class of 1914 will will
celebrate their 25th anniversary with
a dinner at the Belvedere. The Longfellow hotel, the dorms, and the Hopkins club will be the site for other
class reunions.
